(Chains: CWE-366->CWE-416) Description and https://github.com/pjlantz/optee-qemu/blob/main/README.md say "Use after free ... due to a race condition". https://github.com/pjlantz/optee-qemu/blob/main/README.md says "The scenario that triggers the problem is a multi-threaded application where one thread closes the dmabuf file-descriptor at the same time that another thread makes a call to the IOCTL command TEE_IOC_OPEN_SESSION or TEE_IOC_INVOKE referencing that shared memory." so this is a thread race.

(Chains: CWE-1286->CWE-787) Best ref = https://github.com/gz/rust-cpuid/issues/43. "calling [function] with invalid UTF-8 is undefined behavior." Not a deserialization issue since function is just parsing regular UTF-8. Issue is the function assumes correct UTF-8 input and crashes if UTF-8 input is bad. Hence decision to use CWE-1286 over CWE-502.

(Chains: CWE-190->CWE-369) https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/security/advisories/GHSA-34f9-hjfq-rr8j says "vulnerable to a division by zero caused by an integer overflow bug". Offending line given is "tf.raw_ops.UnravelIndex(indices=-0x100000,dims=[0x100000,0x100000])", which suggests underflow but isn't conclusive without seeing function operation. Diff (https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/commit/58b34c6c8250983948b5a781b426f6aa01fd47af) adds checks for both over & underflow. Given lack of hard evidence, will go with author's assertion.

(Chains: CWE-676->CWE-121) https://packetstormsecurity.com/files/167464/Zyxel-Buffer-Overflow-Format-String-Command-Injection.html describes 5 distinct vulnerabilities for this CVE. == Vuln1: "buffer overflow happens due to the unsafe sprintf() call ... which overflows ... the ... array allocated on the stack". == Vuln2: "vulnerability lies in the use of the unsafe __isoc99_fscanf() API function ... [which] allows us to overwrite the ... return address". == Vuln3: "two stack-based buffer overflows caused by the unchecked use of the unsafe API function sprintf()". == Vuln4: "we control the format strings passed as argument to the sprintf() [function]". This leads to memory corruption (SEGFAULT) == Vuln5: "allows [us] to specify additional arbitrary command-line arguments to be passed to tcpdump"

Reference provides a lot of details related to incorrect implementation of threads leading to memory corruption. It is said that "Libpthread built with uClibC using the linuxthreads.old implementation, or with uClibC-ng using the linuxthreads implementation, are both vulnerable to a memory corruption that occurs when a large number of threads are created." Ultimately, this is not related CWE-787, but other types of memory corruption. Out of different options like CWE-789, CWE-770, etc., CWE-770 seems to be the best choice. Note that even though the reference maps to CWE-119, CWE-770 provides a better fit based on the information.

(Chains: CWE-662->CWE-770) Description states "hen Tulip reads or writes to the rx/tx descriptor or copies the rx/tx frame, it doesn't check whether the destination address is its own MMIO address. This can cause the device to trigger MMIO handlers multiple times, possibly leading to a stack or heap overflow." The following reference (https://gitlab.com/qemu-project/qemu/-/issues/1171) states, "DMA reentrancy issue leads to stack overflow". Given that the context is associated with threading (https://gitlab.com/qemu-project/qemu/-/commit/36a894aeb64a2e02871016da1c37d4a4ca109182), CWE-663 leading to CWE-770 makes sense.

(Chains: CWE-190->CWE-122) Description and reference state, "An integer overflow vulnerability exists in the way ESTsoft Alyac 2.5.8.544 parses OLE files. A specially-crafted OLE file can lead to a heap buffer overflow". Reference maps to CWE-680, however that is a named chain, a rare type of CWE entry that was originally intended to give more research focus and understanding to chains back when they were not commonly understood. They are not used often and are discouraged for CVE remapping. We want to be explicit about all parts of the chain, and sometimes the resultant part of the chain can be described with a lower-level CWE.

The following reference (https://crbug.com/1329794) states, "heap-use-after-free" and provides a proof of concept. "`LinkToTextMenuObserver` holds a raw pointer to a `RenderFrameHost` object, but isn't owned by the frame host and doesn't watch for frame host destruction events (for example, via `WebContentsObserver::RenderFrameDeleted(`). Therefore, if an attacker manages to destroy the frame host right after the observer is created but before the timeout task posted in `StartLinkGenerationRequestWithTimeout()` is executed, use-after-free will occur." This doesn't involve 2 separate weaknesses or one leading to another.

"leak the access token assigned at start time by guessing/brute forcing the PID of the jupyter server." does not suggest insufficient randomness because the total space of PID ids is usually fixed. This might indicate an an issue of an insecure default with "`root_dir` that contains the starting user's home directory" because an adversary might be abel to use a user's home directory to access an API along with the guessed PID, but this is all assumptions because there is not enough info given. Going with the NVD Provider mapping for CWE-200 even though this is focused on the technical impact.

"does not properly address XML round-trip issues. An incorrect document can be produced after parsing and serializing". ruby-lang ref has "When parsing and serializing a crafted XML document ... can create a wrong XML document whose structure is different from the original one". https://hackerone.com/reports/1104077 discusses the XML round-trip issues within REXML and has "root cause seems to be incorrect anchoring -- using ^ for beginning of line instead of \A for beginning of string" which likely indicates CWE-777. Research: round-trip issues, which involves converting from format A to B and back to A

desc: "some steps of setup.php file are reachable not only by super-administrators, but by unauthenticated users." zabbix.com ref: "Possible view of the setup pages by unauthenticated users." Commit ref https://git.zabbix.com/projects/ZBX/repos/zabbix/commits/1d97fe75535659d744854c8d818642a1a43234c7 has code changes with a comment that talks about "dealing with a spoofed session cookie... it's... impossible to validate the config file and display any discrepancies." It adds a privilege check if somebody is USER_TYPE_SUPER_ADMIN.

bugzilla bug ref says "dbus-daemon sends back an error reply. This error case is handled in polkit_system_bus_name_get_creds_sync by setting the value of the error parameter, but it still returns TRUE, rather than FALSE... This behavior means that all callers of [a certain function] need to carefully check whether an error was set. If the calling function forgets to check for errors then it will think that the uid of the requesting process is 0". This issue does not map to CWE-252 because the return value is correct, but the code needs to look elsewhere to determine error status.

https://securelist.com/cve-2022-30190-follina-vulnerability-in-msdt-description-and-counteraction/106703/ says "The attacker creates an MS Office document with a link to an external malicious OLE object... such as an HTML file located on a remote server... [a] link in the Target attribute points to the above-mentioned HTML file, inside which a malicious script is written using a special URI scheme [that] runs MSDT. The attacker can then pass, through a set of parameters, any command to this tool for execution on the victimâ€™s system." This could be an authorization issue, but the intended security model is not clear.

Found ref with additional details at https://www.sangfor.com/farsight-labs-threat-intelligence/cybersecurity/cve-2022-34713-microsoft-windows-msdt-remote-code-execution-vulnerability. The ref states "an attacker sends a harmful diagnostic tool (.diagcab) file to a user of a vulnerable system... Once the file has been opened, it writes a malicious executable in C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\StartMenu\Programs\Startup." This describes how an adversary can carry out the attack, but does not give any information on what the root weakness is.

confused deputy issue. tracker.zkoss.org ref says "an attacker may send a forged request... If the forged request contains the nextURI parameter, the AuUploader will try to forward the request internally... Since this is an internal forward, it can access documents located in restricted WEB-INF folder, which exposes internal files such as web.xml, zk.xml and other files located in this directory."

(Chains: CWE-456->CWE-250) ref says ""$user" in zabbix-agent2 is set... in systemd , which is [not installed]... [$user should be set] in [a config file]... otherwise it is executed (started) under root." This is execution with unnecessary privileges, but the primary weakness seems to be not setting the value of a critical variable, so a blank value (empty string) is used.

https://github.com/electron/electron/security/advisories/GHSA-3p22-ghq8-v749 says "obtain access to random bluetooth device without permission". Issue appears to be that, in the absence of an existing listener, the system picks a "default". Fixed (https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/32178/files) by adding code: "if (this.listenerCount('select-bluetooth-device') === 0) { // Cancel it if there are no handlers event.preventDefault();" Picked CWE-862 because this effectively represents bypassing authorization checks.

https://terjanq.medium.com/waf-bypasses-via-0days-d4ef1f212ec describes two multipart parsing issues, but both have the same weakness. (https://github.com/SpiderLabs/ModSecurity/pull/2797 -> https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/modsecurity-request-body-parsing-recent-bypass-issues/ -> https://terjanq.medium.com/waf-bypasses-via-0days-d4ef1f212ec) Issue is due to ambiguity in parsing rules leading to possible different interpretations between ModSecurity and the back end: https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/modsecurity-request-body-parsing-recent-bypass-issues/ says "could result in ModSecurity populating its argument collections with strings that are different from what the web server would see". Input is not malformed and researcher does not indicate ModSecurity misinterprets it - only that there are multiple possible interpretations with differing interpretations resulting in possible security check bypass.

"share the system temporary directory between all users" in https://github.com/netty/netty/security/advisories/GHSA-269q-hmxg-m83q ref. the java function "createTempFile" will create the temp files in a system temp directory allowing all users to view the file. In the same ref this is attempted to be mitigated by "file.setReadable(false, false);", which indicates that all non-owners should not be able to read the file. It seems like the issue is that a user can simply upload PLC code which can do malicious things, but it is unclear what weakness allows this, so going with the NVD Provider maping of CWE-668

gist.github.com ref says "Authentication status is stored in the $_SESSION['authenticated'] variable, which is checked prior to checking authentication credentials. Note: wpscan.com maps to CWE-287 but NVD Provider (also WPScan) maps to CWE-862. Vendor's changeset ref says "unauthenticated user could update the CSS styles"

This is fixed by "store the initial calling package in the intent"

Desc: "someone watching [a temporary file] be created the first time could potentially intercept the file the following time." In openwall ref: "The name for the temporary file holding user changes is obtained once and reused each time the user saves... Temporary files are opened without passing the `O_EXCL` or `O_NOFOLLOW` flags... After that, a new file under the attacker's control is created in its stead that contains malicous data. This is the race condition that needs to be won.". Research: file pre-creation.

"bypass 2FA enforcement... by using Resource Owner Password Credentials grant to obtain an access token without using 2FA" indicates some type of weak authN. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/355028 - before deciding to fix, devs suggested documenting "Tokens generated before 2FA is enforced will remain valid." Fix includes "forbid requests of an access token in exchange for the resource owner credentials from users that are required to set up two factor". Therefore, issue is failure to effectively revoke access. CWE-GAP: revocation in access control

https://github.com/vooon/ntpd_driver/issues/9 describes an issue due to "usage of strings from parameters as topic name". This can result in nodes that "subscribe to a wrong topic", potentially maliciously controlled one. It also describes that "parameters are usually set in parameter files, they can also be changed by nodes" which means the developers might not realize that these settings can be controlled externally.

(Chains: CWE-346->CWE-406) "ddos reflection attack" in desc. Researchers find 4 UDP open ports on the service. Two of which are susceptible to a reflection amplification attack "we find that both 32410 and 32414 respond" in ref:https://github.com/lixiang957/CVE-2021-33959. the freebuf ref describes the issue as "attacker forges a large number of victim IP requests and sends them to the corresponding open service. Usually, such open service does not verify the source but completes the response immediately. In this way, larger and more response packets are sent to the victim IP, thereby realizing traffic reflection."

(Chains: CWE-346->CWE-406) "ddos reflection attack" in desc. Researchers find 4 UDP open ports on the service. Usually, such open service does not verify the source but completes the response immediately. In this way, larger and more response packets are sent to the victim IP, thereby realizing traffic reflection."

from desc: "Comparing integer values against numeric values can result in a slow sequential scan" code.jeremyevans.net Ref Desc: "Forcing Sequential Scans... When doing a comparison between an integer or bigint value and a numeric value, PostgreSQL will implicitly cast the integer or bigint value to numeric, then do the comparison .. [In some cases] PostgreSQL will not use any index on the table, because the index is on the value of the column". Research/Gap: this cast is not "incorrect", so CWE-681 does not apply; the comparison is inefficient - not incorrect - so CWE-697 does not apply. CWE-1067 is for problems with the SQL queries themselves, not the inefficiencies in the SQL engine.

WRITE", "AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on READ", "AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000000 ... caused by a READ", and one stack trace shows "AddressSanitizer: SEGV ... caused by a WRITE". (All quoted stack traces use MovieAddFrame; reference has another trace that does not use MovieAddFrame and corresponds to CVE-2022-35086.)
